overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students use a situation to identify unknown independent and dependent quantities. They analyze a graph representing the situation, interpret the meaning of ordered pairs, and identify the unit rate. Students then use the graph to solve an equation by graphing a horizontal line at the value of the dependent quantity to identify the independent quantity.

overview_item_data_items: I can analyze the relationship between the independent and the dependent variables in a graph and relate the variables to an equation.
I can use graphs to solve one-step, real-world problems.
I can write an equation to represent a real-world problem.

Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.

Many real-world problems, such as those involving constant speed, list and graph ordered pairs of distances and times, and write an equation in two variables to represent the relationship between distance and time.
You can use a graph to identify an independent quantity by graphing a horizontal line at the dependent quantity's value.
When using a graph to answer a question, often you can only provide an approximation rather than an exact answer.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students analyze a real-world situation and estimate unknown data values.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using a Graph to Determine Unknown Quantities
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students interpret the meaning of ordered pairs and determine the unit rate from a graph.
Students analyze a graph and write an equation to represent a situation.
Students compare equations that represent additive and multiplicative relationships.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
